Gloria‐Soria A ,
Mendiola SY ,
Morley VJ ,
Alto BW ,
Turner PE . Prior evolution in stochastic versus constant temperatures affects RNA virus evolvability at a thermal extreme. Ecol Evol. 2020; 10: 5440– 5450. 10.1002/ece3.6287

fn.p: This work was supported by: U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) Research Supplement to Promote Diversity in Health‐Related Research 3R01AI091646‐04S1 to A.G‐S (PI: J. Yin and co‐PI: P.E.T.); U.S. National Science Foundation (NSF) Graduate Research Fellowship Grant DGE‐1122492 to V.J.M.; a Mellon Mays Undergraduate Fellowship to S.Y.M.; the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Cooperative Agreement Number U01CK000509 (A.G.‐S, PI. T. Andreadis); and P.E.T. affiliate membership in the NSF BEACON Center for Evolution in Action. The contents of this work are solely the responsibility of the authors and do not necessarily represent the official views of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention or the Department of Health and Human Services. The virus isolates originated from a previous experiment supported by a Gaylord Donnelly Environmental Postdoctoral Fellowship from the Yale Institute for Biospheric Studies to B.W.A.
